bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George E. Armstrong, August 12, 1952

div1.p: Hench informs Armstrong about the Camp Lazear memorial and his concern about the park and Building No. 1 being named after Finlay. Hench believes that the Army Medical Corps and the State Department should participate in the dedication. He encloses an extensive report on the impending memorialization of Camp Lazear and the participation of the U.S. Army and State Department in the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George E. Armstrong, August 12, 1952
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
August 12, 1952
Copy
General George Armstrong
The Surgeon General
Department of the Army
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear General Armstrong:
div1.p:
If their plans are completed on schedule, the Cuban Government, to be
specific - its Health Department, expects to “dedicate” certain memorials
on the site of Walter Reed's old “Camp Lazear” near Havana, Cuba, the
dedication being tentatively set to coincide with an International Congress
the end of September. Although the Cuban physician chiefly responsible for
these actions appears to have the best of intentions and a fair-minded at-
titude toward Walter Reed and his colleagues, the Cuban newspapers continue
to refer erroneously to Camp Lazear and the remains of Building No. 1, as
the spot where Doctor Finlay carried on his own work. Camp Lazear is being
spoken of erroneously in certain quarters as Parque Finlay and Walter Reed's
Building No. 1 as Caseta de Finlay. I believe, or at least hope, these errors
will be corrected but it is a matter of historical accuracy and of the pride
of the U. S. Army Medical Corps that the memorials be properly named.

For reasons, which are appended, it seems to me and others quite important
that the U. S. Army, particularly the Medical Corps of the U. S. Army,
and our State Department, participate in the dedication and I know it is
the intention of those Cubans chiefly preparing the memorial that invita-
tions shall be sent officially in the near future.

May I urgently request that you ask one of your colleagues to review the
enclosures, first being some suggested requests of my own, the rest con-
cerning the background of the present memorialization.
div1.closer:
Sincerely Yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: If you think that I should send a copy of the enclosure to the State
Department prior to their receipt of any communication from the Cuban
Government, I would appreciate it greatly if you would tell me to whom
I should address a copy of the enclosure
